questions.text: A 70-year-old chronic smoker is being evaluated for chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss. On examination, pallor was noted. Peripheral smear revealed macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. Stool examination showed elevated calprotectin and a positive guaiac test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease presenting as jejunoileitis. This is evidenced by the presence of features of malabsorption such as steatorrhea, chronic diarrhea, and vitamin B12 deficiency anemia.

The fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin are elevated in inflammatory conditions like inflammatory bowel disease, but not in irritable bowel syndrome. 

The stool guaiac test or guaiac fecal occult blood test (gFOBT) reveals the presence of microscopic levels of blood suggesting Crohn's disease. Gross bleeding per rectum is more characteristic of ulcerative colitis.  

Additionally, smoking is a risk factor for Crohn's disease. However, it is a protective factor in ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: A 9-year old child presents chronic fatigue, growth retardation and epistaxis. On further evaluation, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia and anemia was found. X-ray of the femur shows the following. Bone marrow biopsy showed cells with wrinkled tissue paper appearance. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features, X-ray showing Erlenmeyer flask deformity and bone marrow biopsy showing cells with wrinkled tissue paper appearance suggest Gaucher’s disease (type I)

Gaucher's disease is a genetic disorder in which glucocerebroside accumulates in cells and certain organs due to the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase (β-glucosidase).

It is the most common lysosomal storage disorder.

It is characterized by the following clinical features:

  • Painless hepatomegaly and splenomegaly 
  • Liver cirrhosis
  • Hypersplenism and pancytopenia
  • Bleeding tendencies
  • Bone pain
  • Osteoporosis, pathological fractures (Erlenmeyer flask deformity)
  • Neurological symptoms such as developmental delay, hypertonia, strabismus, supranuclear gaze palsy (seen in type 3)

Treatment: Enzyme replacement therapy is available in the form of 

  • Human recombinant acid β-glucosidase (Imiglucerase)
  • Velaglucerase alfa
  • Taliglucerase alfa

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

S. No.

Disease

Enzyme Deficiency

Lipid

Accumulating

Clinical Symptoms

1

Tay–Sachs disease

Hexosaminidase A

Ganglioside

Mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness

2

Sandhoff's disease

Hexosaminidase A and B

Globoside & Ganglioside

Similar to Tay–Sachs disease but also has hepatosplenomegaly and skeletal dysplasias

3

Fabry's disease

α-Galactosidase

Globotriaosyl-ceramide

Skin rash, kidney failure (full symptoms only in males; X-linked recessive)

4

Arylsulfatase A

3-Sulfogalactosyl-ceramide

Mental retardation and psychologic disturbances in adults; demyelination

5

Mental retardation; myelin almost absent

6

β-Glucosidase

7

Sphingomyelinase

Enlarged liver and spleen, mental retardation; fatal in early life

8

Ceramidase

Ceramide

Hoarseness, dermatitis, skeletal deformation, mental retardation; fatal in early life

questions.text: A 24-year-old pregnant woman has completed her 1st antenatal visit under the maternal and child health program (MCH). Now she is 14 weeks pregnant. How many more antenatal visits does she need to complete to fulfill the minimum requirement for antenatal visits under the MCH?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the lady should complete 3 more visits to fulfill the minimum requirement of antenatal visits under MCH.

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to MCH is 4.

  • 1st visit – within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected.
  • 2nd visit – between 14 and 26 weeks
  • 3rd visit – between 28 and 34 weeks
  • 4th visit – between 36 weeks and term

It is advised that the woman should visit the medical officer at the PHC for an antenatal check-up during 3rd visit.

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to the WHO (not MCH), is 8.

The ideal number of antenatal visits a mother should take to the antenatal clinic is:

  • Once a month during the first 7 months
  • Twice a month during the next month
  • Once a week, thereafter if everything is normal.

questions.text: A middle-aged obese female patient has recently been diagnosed with type 2 DM. The best initial drug of choice for the clinical management of type 2 diabetes mellitus in obese patients is ______
questions.solution:
Metformin is the best initial drug of choice for the clinical management of diabetes mellitus in an obese patient.

Metformin

  • Drug of choice in obese Type 2 diabetes mellitus patients
  • Mechanism of Action: Reduced hepatic glucose production
  • Advantages :
    • Modest weight loss
    • No hypoglycemia
    • No plasma level monitoring
  • Disadvantages :
    • Nausea, Diarrhea
    • Lactic acidosis
    • Vitamin B12 deficiency
  • Contraindications :
    • Liver failure
    • Chronic renal failure
    • Chronic hepatic failure
    • Alcoholics

questions.text: A lady wants LASIK surgery for her daughter. Which of the following is not an eligibility criteria for LASIK?

choices.text: Stable refraction for the past 1 year

questions.solution:
Age of 15 years is not a criteria for LASIK surgery. LASIK surgery is performed after 18 years of age.

Laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) is performed

  • using excimer laser
  • in individuals aged > 18 years
  • in individuals who have a stable refractive error
  • in individuals who have had unsatisfactory results with non-surgical treatment
  • in individuals in whom corneal-thinning disorders such as keratoconus have been ruled out

questions.text: To diagnose a child with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, symptoms should begin before what age?
questions.solution:
To diagnose ADHD, symptoms have to be present before 12 years of age.

According to DSM-5, six or more symptoms of inattention for children up to age 16 years, or five or more symptoms for adolescents age 17 years and older and adults are required to make a diagnosis. Symptoms of inattention/hyperactivity must be present for at least 6 months.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions will you perform the Kasai procedure?
questions.solution:
Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy) is done for extrahepatic biliary atresia. In the Kasai procedure, the occluded extrahepatic bile ducts are excised and a jejunal Roux loop is anastomosed to the hepatic hilum.

Extrahepatic biliary atresia (EHBA) is defined as a partial or total absence of permeable bile duct between porta hepatis and the duodenum. It is due to inflammatory fibrosis of the biliary tree. It leads to obstruction to bile flow thereby causing leaking of conjugated bilirubin into the circulation.

Associated anomalies include cardiac lesions, polysplenia, situs inversus, absent vena cava, and a preduodenal portal vein.

HIDA scan is the investigation of choice for EHBA. Intraoperative cholangiogram is the gold standard for diagnosis.

Management of extrahepatic biliary atresia
Type I

Atresia restricted to the common bile duct

Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy
Type II

Atresia of the common hepatic duct

 Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy)
Type III

Atresia of the right and left hepatic duct

Infants with biliary atresia, who do not achieve successful drainage after Kasai's procedure, require liver transplantation within the first year of life. It is the most common reason for liver transplantation in children.

Kasai procedure:

questions.text: Pap smear is ________
questions.solution:
Pap smear is a screening test. In case of positive test further investigations should be done.

Pap Smear Schedule

  • Time for initiation: 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse.
  • Women aged 21-29 years: Every 3 years(earlier it was done annually)
  • Women aged 30-65 years: Pap test + HPV testing every 5 years.
  • Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If suspicious PAP, screening till 75 years.
  • HIV+ women: annual checkup until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life.
  • HPV DNA testing in combination with PAP improves the sensitivity of screening.

Ayres spatula and endocervical brush are the instruments used for the pap test.

Ayres spatula:

  • One end is blunt and the other end is bifid.
  • Blunt end is used to take samples for vaginal cytology.
  • Bifid end is used to take Pap smear

Endocervical brush:

questions.text: The egg in cup heart is seen in:
questions.solution:
Egg in a Cup appearance is seen with Constrictive pericarditis.

  • Constrictive pericarditis results with calcification of the pericardium. There is a straightening of the right heart border and roughening of the cardiac outline as a result of pleuropericardial thickening. Calcification has a characteristic distribution involving the anterior and lateral aspects of the heart.
  • Constrictive pericarditis is a type of pericarditis which leads to diastolic dysfunction and potential symptoms of right heart failure. Characterized by fibrous or calcific constrictive thickening of the pericardium, which prevents normal diastolic filling of the heart.
  • MRI is the investigation done to assess the thickness of pericardium.

 

Note : 

Egg on side appearance - Transposition of great arteries (CXR)

Egg in a cup appearance - Constrictive pericarditis (CXR), Also seen in Renal papillary necrosis (In urography)

questions.text: What is the size of the intravenous cannula shown below?
questions.solution:
The size of the given cannula is 24G (yellow).

This cannula is used to gain IV access in the pediatric age group. The flow rate in this cannula is 20ml/min.

Related Pearl: Color Coding of Intravenous Cannulae

Size Color Coding Flow Rate Uses
14G Orange 270ml/min Trauma Patients, Rapid, Large Volume replacement
16G Grey 236ml/min Trauma Patients, Major Surgery, Intra Partum/Post Partum, GI bleeds, Multiple blood transfers, High volume of Fluids
17G White 125ml/min Newly added
18G Green 103 ml/min Blood products, delivery of irritant medications, major surgery, contrast study
20G Pink 67ml/min General use IV maintenance, IV antibiotics, IV analgesics
22G Blue 42 ml/min Small or Fragile veins, Cytotoxic Therapy
24G Yellow 20ml/min For pediatric Usage
26G Violet 13ml/min Newly added

questions.text: Among the following, which isotope is used in nuclear scanning?
questions.solution:
Technetium agents based on technetium-99m (Tc-99m) radioisotope are the most frequently used agents in nuclear imaging.

The radioactive technetium can be chelated to a number of different compounds to create specific radiopharmaceuticals and optimize imaging of various structures. The half-life of Tc 99m is 6 hours. It produces gamma rays of 140 keV.

Iodine 125 (I 125), caesium 137 (Cs 137), and iridium 192 (Ir 192) are used in radiotherapy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented to the OPD with a 4 x 2 cm painless lump in the left breast. She is planned for a mastectomy. Sentinel lymph node biopsy done showed involvement of level 1 lymph nodes. Which of the following lymph nodes will not be affected in her case?
questions.solution:
Interpectoral lymph nodes are level 2 axillary lymph nodes. Level 1 axillary lymph nodes include anterior, lateral, and posterior/subscapular nodes.

Related Pearl: Lymphatic drainage of breast

The lymphatics of the breast drain predominantly into

  • The axillary lymph nodes (85%)
  • Internal mammary lymph nodes
  • Posterior intercostal/Interpectoral/ Rotter’s lymph nodes

The axillary nodes are arranged in the following groups:

Level I (Lymph nodes located lateral to pectoralis minor muscle):

  • Lateral, along the axillary vein - drains most of upper limb
  • Anterior (external mammary group or pectoral group), along the lateral thoracic vessels - drains most of breast.(1st relay station for lymph)
  • Posterior (scapular group), along the subscapular vessels

Level II (Lymph nodes located superficial or deep to pectoralis minor muscle):

  • Central, embedded in fat in the centre of the axilla- receive drainage from Level I groups

Level III (Lymph nodes located medial to pectoralis minor muscle):

  • Apical (sub-clavicular group), which lie above the level of the pectoralis minor tendon in continuity with the lateral nodes and which receive the efferents of all the other axillary groups and drains in to subclavian lymphatic trunk.

Interpectoral (Rotters node) - a few nodes lying between the pectoralis major and minor muscles.(Level II)

Internal mammary nodes drain posterior one-third of breast.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a ​history of perianal pain is brought to the OPD. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine picrate. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The test done in the scenario is Barberio test. It is used to detect seminal fluid.

When saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Other options: 

Option B: Florence test: 

  • The suspected seminal stain is extracted with 10% hydrochloric acid and a drop of it is placed over a slide.
  • A coverslip is placed over it and a drop of Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water) is made to run under the coverslip.
  • If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately.

Option C: Takayama test (Haemochromogen crystal test): 

  • The test is used to detect suspected bloodstains. Small piece of suspected material is added on a glass slide.
  • Then, 2-3 drops of Takayama reagent is added and covered with a coverslip.
  • If it is a bloodstain, pink feathery crystals of haemochromogen or reduced alkaline haematin appear in a few minutes.

Option D: Teichmann test (Haemin Crystal Test): 

  • The test is used to detect suspected bloodstains.
  • Small piece of suspected material is placed on a glass slide. Then, 2-3 drops of glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride are added to the glass slide and covered with a coverslip. The slide is then heated.
  • If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of haemin or haematin chloride appear.
  • When hydrogen peroxide is added, the haematin crystals give bubbles of gas.

questions.text: In modern obstetrics, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring the fetus of an Rh-negative sensitized mother?
questions.solution:
MCA doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for the monitoring of fetuses in Rh-negative sensitized mothers.

MCA PSV is enhanced due to increased cardiac output and decreased viscosity of fetal blood. 

If the MCA PSV exceeds 1.5 MoM (multiples of the median) and the gestational age is less than 34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling should be considered. MCA Doppler PSV has replaced amniocentesis as the preferred test for the detection of anemia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being punched in the right side of his face. His plain radiograph is shown below. Which of the following bones maximally contributes to the region fractured?
questions.solution:
The plain radiograph shows a fracture of the floor of the orbit. The maximum contribution to the floor of the orbit is by the maxilla.

Boundaries of the bony orbit:

  • Roof: 
    • The orbital plate of the frontal bone 
    • Sphenoid bone (small part)
  • Floor: Thin plate of bone that also forms the roof of the maxillary sinus
    • The orbital plate of the maxilla
    • Zygomatic bone (anterolateral)
    • Orbital process of palatine bone (posteromedial)
  • Medial wall:
    • Maxilla
    • Lacrimal bone
    • Ethmoid bone
    • Sphenoid bone
  • Lateral wall: 
    • Zygomatic bone (anterior)
    • Greater wing of sphenoid (posterior)
    • Sphenozygomatic suture.

The orbital floor can be fractured by trauma to the orbit as seen in falls, motor vehicle accidents, and assaults. The image given shows X-ray Water's view with a 'teardrop' sign. The orbital contents leak out of the fractured orbital floor, giving it a teardrop-like appearance.

questions.text: A child is found to have the findings shown in the image below, on examination of the lower back. Identify the condition:
questions.solution:
The given image showing a tuft of hair over the lower back is suggestive of spina bifida.

Spina bifida is a general term used for neural tube defects affecting the spinal region and associated with splitting of the vertebral arches. It is characterized by gaps in the vertebral arches and may or may not involve the underlying neural tissue. 

The 3 main types of spina bifida:

  1. Spina bifida occulta - This is the mildest form of spina bifida. The defect in the vertebral arches is covered by the skin. The splits in the vertebrae are so small that the spinal cord does not protrude. The skin at the site of the lesion may be normal. They present only with a tuft of hair over the lower back.
  2. Meningocele - The defect in the vertebra allows the meninges to protrude through the defect.
  3. Myelomeningocele (meningomyelocele) - A defect in the vertebral column allows the spinal cord with the meningeal coverings to protrude. 

Other options:

Option A: Encephalocele refers to the protrusion of intracranial tissue through a midline bony defect.

The two images below show babies with encephalocele, i.e. midline neural tube defects of the cranial end.

Option B: Omphalocele is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

Option C: Rachischisis is the most severe type of neural tube defect, where the entire neural tube fails to close. Rachischisis can occur in the spinal cord or brain regions of the neural tube. The exposed neural tissues often become necrotic. 

The image given below shows craniorachischisis.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with hepatitis B infection. Which of the following markers will always be present in his serum, even during recurrences, or if he develops chronic hepatitis?
questions.solution:
A patient who has had exposure to HBV will have Anti HBc antibodies even when he has moved into the chronic or recurrent stages. IgM anti-HBc reappears during acute recurrences while IgG Anti HBc is found in chronic states. 

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA
Acute HBV - Early-phase, high infectivity

+

 - + - IgM +++

Acute HBV -Window phase

-

 - - - IgM +

Acute HBV - recovery phase

-

 + - + IgG +/-
Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

 + - - + IgG +

HBV infection in the recent past

 - + - - IgG -

HBV infection in the remote past

 - - - +/- IgG -

Post-vaccination

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of COPD presents with increased shortness of breath. His ABG analysis reveals pH - 7.24; pCO2 - 60 mm Hg, pO2- 52 mmHg, HCO3 - 27 mmol/L. What is the most probable underlying acid-base disorder?
questions.solution:
The underlying acid-base disorder is respiratory acidosis.

  • Step 1: A pH of 7.24 signifies acidosis.
  • Step 2: A plasma HCO3- is 27 mEq/L is within normal limits. This is very likely to be due to compensation as it does not reflect the direction of the pH change.
  • Step 3: A pCO2 of 60 mmHg along with an acidotic pH signifies respiratory acidosis. 
  • Step 4: The expected compensatory increase in HCO3- can be calculated using the following formula:
  • Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 X Δ PaCO2 (as COPD is a chronic condition and the presentation of the patient is not acute)
  • Thus, the increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x (60-40) = 8 mEq/L
  • Therefore expected HCO3- is 24 + 8 = 32 mEq/L.
  • The actual HCO3- measured is 27 mEq/L (which is less than the expected value) indicating that there could be a component of metabolic acidosis also.
  • But, the predominant disorder is respiratory acidosis and thus it is the best answer.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 8 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

questions.text: A 12 year old boy came to the OPD with scald injury of arm. The lesion was  pink, oozing and painful to touch. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Scald injury (hot liquids) with pink, oozing and painful lesion is suggestive of a 2nd degree burn. Second-degree wounds is treated with daily dressing changes with topical antibiotics (Silver sulphadiazine cream), cotton gauze and elastic wraps.

 
First degree

Superficial 

second

 Deep second Third degree
Painful Painful Pain on pin prick Painless
Erythematous

Erythematous,

moist

 Pale, Mottled Hard leathery eschar
Blanch on touch Blanch on touch Not blanch Black in color
Not blister often blister    
No scarring Spontaneous re-epithelialisation in 1-2 weeks Severe scarring,
re-epithelialisation in 2-5week		 Excision & skin grafting needed

questions.text: Corticosteroid indicated for the stimulation of fetal lung maturation in preterm labor______
questions.solution:
Betamethasone is indicated for the stimulation of fetal lung maturation in preterm labor.

Dexamethasone, another long-acting glucocorticoid is also indicated. It has benefits such as less risk of intraventricular hemorrhage and a shorter length of stay in the NICU.

Maternal administration of glucocorticoids is advised in preterm labor when the period of gestation is less than 34 weeks. Intramuscular injection of either betamethasone or dexamethasone is given.

Dosage: 

  • Betamethasone(Betnesol): Two doses of 12 mg each, given 24 hours apart.
  • Dexamethasone: Four doses of 6 mg each, given every 12 hours.

This helps in fetal lung maturation and minimizes the incidence of:

  • Respiratory distress syndrome
  • Intraventricular hemorrhage
  • Necrotizing enterocolitis

It is beneficial when the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours after the first dose.

questions.text: The device shown in the given image is used for the monitoring of:
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a pulse oximeter. Pulse oximetry is used for monitoring pulse rate and oxygen saturation of a patient.

A small sensor is placed on the finger, toe, earlobe, or another convenient place.

The relative absorption of light by oxyhemoglobin (HbO) and deoxyhemoglobin is assessed by measuring the amount of red and infrared light emerging from tissues traversed by light rays and processed by the device, producing an oxygen saturation level.

Pulse oximetry does not measure the absolute content or the partial pressures of oxygen or carbon dioxide.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with complaints of shortness of breath and tiredness. There is no history of reactive airway disease or heart diseases previously. She has a history of breast cancer for which breast conservation surgery and chemoradiation were done. On examination, there were engorged neck veins and JVP showed rapid x and y descent and Chest Xray is as below.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the JVP findings of rapid X and Y descent  are suggestive of constrictive pericarditis.

Constrictive pericarditis:

  • It is the condition where a thickened, fibrotic, and often calcified pericardium restricts the diastolic filling of the heart.
  • In developing countries, infectious etiologies like tuberculosis or viral infections are the most common cause of this condition.
  • Cardiac surgery and radiation therapy are also common causes.
  • Other causes include connective tissue disease, uremia, neoplasm, or idiopathic.
  • Clinically the patients present with dyspnea, orthopnea, and fatigue.
  • JVP findings - There is a rapid 'x' and 'y' descent. The rapid 'y' descent is more prominent and reflects rapid early ventricular diastolic filling. This occurs due to the constricting pericardium, increasing the atrial pressures.

Diagnosis:

  • Diagnosis is difficult and is confirmed by multiple investigations
  • Hallmark findings of pericardial constriction are pericardial thickening, calcification, and abnormal ventricular diastolic function.
  • The X-ray can be normal or there may be non-specific cardiac enlargement, calcification, and roughened cardiac outline.
  • Echo can assess the hemodynamic function but it is accurate in identifying pericardial thickening.
  • CT and MRI are more sensitive investigations.
  • CT has an edge over MRI as it can detect calcification associated with this condition.
  • Pericardial thickness of > 4mm along with clinical features of constriction is highly suggestive of this diagnosis.
  • Cardiac MR may show diastolic septal bounce.
  • Hepatomegaly and ascites can be seen associated with this condition.

Constrictive pericarditis will have prominent y descent, prominent x descent, and Kussmaul's sign. Normally, the venous pressure should fall by at least 3 mmHg with inspiration. Kussmaul’s sign is defined by either a rise or a lack of fall of the JVP with inspiration.

Other important conditions and their JVP tracings are

  • In Cardiac tamponade, the jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing of the patient will have a prominent x descent but an absent y descent.
  • Atrioventricular block will have cannon a waves
  • Atrial fibrillation will have absent a wave
  • Tricuspid regurgitation will have accentuated v wave with rapid y descent
  • Tricuspid stenosis will have prolonged y wave

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Histopathological image shows acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis/intercapillary glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

Three renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Glomerular lesions:
    • Capillary basement membrane thickening
    • Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
    • Nodular glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease
  • Renal vascular lesions, principally hyaline arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis

Renal histopathology in:

  • Amyloidosis: Glomerular deposits appearing as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid
  • Lupus nephritis: Immune complex deposits in the mesangium or along the entire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall; lipid droplets in the sclerosed area.

questions.text: All of the following are contraindications of IUD usage except:
questions.solution:
Cardiac problems is not a contraindication in IUD usage.

 

IUD Usage
Absolute contraindications Relative contraindications

suspected pregnancy,

PID,

vaginal bleeding of unknown etiology,

Carcinoma cervix/uterus/adnexa/other pelvic tumors,

previous ectopic pregnancy.

anemia,

menorrhagia,

history of PID since the last pregnancy,

purulent cervical discharge, distortions of the uterine cavity due to fibroids,

uterine malformations,

unmotivated person. 

Hence, the best answer here is cardiac problems.

questions.text: The only abductor of the vocal cord is ______
questions.solution:
Posterior cricoarytenoid is the only intrinsic muscle of the larynx that causes abduction of vocal cords.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)
Action
Muscle
Opening of the inlet of larynx
Thyroepiglotticus
Closing of the inlet of larynx
Aryepiglotticus, Interarytenoids
Abductor of vocal cords
Posterior cricoarytenoid
Adductor of vocal cords
Lateral cricoarytenoid
Tensor of vocal cords
Cricothyroid
Relaxer of vocal cord
Thyroarytenoid
Modulator of larynx
Vocalis

Safety muscle of larynx: Posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue: Genioglossus

The muscle of whispering: Lateral cricoarytenoid

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male undergoes bilateral adrenalectomy for phaeochromocytoma. On the third postoperative day, the boy feels lethargic and tired. Blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, there is no sign of bleed. What could be the cause of this?
questions.solution:
The clinical features given in the question are suggestive of Addisonian crisis.

Addisonian crisis is a life-threatening condition caused due to sudden insufficiency of adrenal hormones. Normally, adrenal corticosteroids help to retain sodium and maintain normal intravascular volume. Sudden lack of these hormones causes excessive loss of sodium, decreased intravascular volume, low blood pressure and eventually circulatory collapse.

The causes are either primary or secondary. Primary causes include adrenal haemorrhage, acute infection, etc, while the secondary causes include surgery, cessation of steroid therapy, postpartum pituitary necrosis, etc.

Treatment includes fluid and glucocorticoid replacement.

questions.text: Which of the following malignancies is most commonly associated with the paraneoplastic manifestation shown below?
questions.solution:
This image shows velvety warty hyperpigmentation on the front of the neck called acanthosis nigricans. By far, the commonest site of underlying neoplasm is the gastrointestinal tract (70–90%), and gastric adenocarcinoma is the most frequent.

Production by tumor cells of either transforming growth factor α (TGF-α) or cytokines that activate insulin‐like growth factors or their cutaneous receptors has been proposed as the pathogenetic mechanism.

Related Pearl: Paraneoplastic dermatoses

Cutaneous markers and their commonly associated internal malignancy:

Skin condition Most commonly associated malignancy
Acanthosis nigricans Gastric adenocarcinoma
Acanthosis palmaris Bronchial carcinoma
Sign of LeserTrélat Gastrointestinal adenocarcinoma
Acquired-ichthyosis Hodgkin disease
Pityriasis rotunda Hepatocellular carcinoma
Paraneoplastic pigmentation Small cell bronchial carcinoma
Acrokeratosis paraneoplastica Squamous cell carcinoma of the upper respiratory or gastrointestinal
tracts
Erythema gyratum-repens Lung cancer
Necrolytic migratory erythema Glucagon secreting
pancreatic islet cell adenoma
Dermatomyositis Lung cancer in men, breast and gynaecological tumours in women and colorectal cancers in both sexes
Scleroderma‐like skin changes Carcinoid syndrome
Paraneoplastic pemphigus B‐cell proliferations and thymoma or thymoma‐like neoplasms; specifically Non Hodgkin's lymphoma (42%)
Dermatitis herpetiformis Lymphoma
Porphyria cutanea- tarda and variegate porphyrias Hepatocellular Carcinoma
Erythroderma and exfoliative dermatitis Mycosis fungoides or Sézary syndrome
Pyoderma gangrenosum Hematological malignancy
Sweet syndrome Hematological malignancy
Migratory thrombo-phlebitis (Trousseau's syndrome) Carcinoma Pancreas

questions.text: After successful delivery of the baby, the obstetrician witnesses that the episiotomy performed has extended away backwards beyond the perineal body. Which among the following structures is likely to be injured in this case?
questions.solution:
The structure injured in an episiotomy done posteriorly beyond the perineal body is the external anal sphincter. 

The lacerations of the perineum have been divided into four degrees:

  • First degree- laceration is restricted to the skin of the fourchette
  • Second degree- muscles of the perineal body are torn through
  • Third degree- the tear extends partially backward through the external anal sphincter
  • Fourth degree- the external anal sphincter is torn and anal mucosa is also involved

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: Specificity of a screening test is the ability of a test to detect ____
questions.solution:
Specificity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who don’t have the disease or the true negatives.

Sensitivity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who have the disease.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ Accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence
